Elon Musk: The amount of indoctrination that's happening in schools and universities is far beyond what parents realize ---

“The amount of indoctrination that's happening in schools and universities is, I think, far beyond what parents realize.

twitter.content:
Elon Musk: The amount of indoctrination that's happening in schools and universities is far beyond what parents realize ---

“The amount of indoctrination that's happening in schools and universities is, I think, far beyond what parents realize. 

Let me give you an example that

posts.raw_content:
Read this article about why US Presidents don't have to obey the courts: https://revealnews.org/blog/a-brief-history-of-presidents-telling-so-called-judges-to-get-lost/

There is a history of presidents ignoring the courts. The "Merryman power" is named after the instance where Abraham Lincoln suspended the writ of habeas corpus. Chief Justice Taney ruled that the Constitution gave that power to Congress, not the president. Lincoln ignored the ruling and the constitutional assignment of power to Congress.

From the article, University of St. Thomas law professor Michael Paulsen says on Departmentalism:

>“The power of constitutional interpretation is a divided, shared power,” Paulsen argued, “incident to the functions of each of the branches of the national government — and to instruments of state governments, and of juries, as well — with none of these actors literally bound by the views of any of the others.”

Thomas Jefferson also outlined Departmentalism in 1790:

>"each department is truly independent of the others, and has an equal right to decide for itself what is the meaning of the constitution"

This empowers President Trump to interpret the Constitution for himself for his actions. Article II, Section 2, Clause 1 of the U.S. Constitution grants the President the "Power to grant Reprieves and Pardons for Offenses against the United States, except in Cases of Impeachment."

This has historically been interpreted to mean "federally", but debated because the states are part of the United States. It doesn't directly say federally.

In addition, considering that this specific case involves a national election, it does involve a crime against the United States. Therefore Trump would be in his power to intervene on this interpretation, with support of the Constitution. He doesn't need to ask the courts what they think on this matter.
